fields.headline: News in brief
fields.bodyText: Taxi driver sees hijacker drive over cliff A taxi driver whose car was hijacked at knifepoint on Boxing Day watched the thief plunge to his death from a 120ft cliff. Brian Tate, 41, who was forced out of his car by a man in his 20s, saw his vehicle being driven over the cliff at Marsden Grotto car park in South Shields and crashing on to rocks below. He called the emergency services. The young man, who died instantly, had not been identified by police yesterday. A resident said: "A number of people have died after trying to take their lives and jumping over ... There are signs on the coast asking people to ring the Samaritans if they are in despair." Helen Carter 70,000 go online to find a new job over Christmas Tens of thousands of Britons went online this Christmas to find a new job, it has emerged. An analysis suggests that more than 70,000 people spent part of Christmas Day or Boxing Day surfing for a new employer in an attempt to beat the competition. The study, by jobsite.co.uk, found that most jobhunters were looking for vacancies in retail and customer support. An earlier poll by the website found that about a quarter of Britons dislike their job, with around 47% having a bad day at least once a week. Four in 10 say it has a harmful effect on their health. Agency Town plans tribute to Captain Mainwaring Historians want to commemorate Britain's most famous Home Guard platoon in stone. A civic society in Thetford, Norfolk, is planning to put up a statue of Captain Mainwaring - leader of the fictional Walmington-on-Sea Home Guard in the BBC comedy series Dad's Army. Dad's Army was filmed in Thetford in the 1960s and 70s and the cast stayed in local hotels. The Thetford Society thinks that a statue of the captain, played by the actor Arthur Lowe, would be a fitting way to mark the show's link with the town and commemorate the work of real Home Guard platoons during the second world war.
